text.p: India's leading industrialised states on Tuesday vied with each other to lure private investment.

Politicians from the western states of Gujarat and Maharashtra -- India's most industrialised states -- and from Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's Karnataka state in south India invited investors at a conference in Bombay to do business in their regions.

Maharashtra Chief Minister Manohar Joshi announced "Advantage Maharashtra", a conference to be organised by the state next month, where more than 50 projects totalling around $5.0 billion would be offered to private investors.
"I have requested those who want to invest to come with cheques in their hands...I will take the cheques and give them the projects," he said.

R.V. Deshpande, Industry Minister of Karnataka, whose capital Bangalore is described as India's Silicon valley, listed the advantages of his state, which he said included skilled manpower and a low rate of labour disputes.
Deshpande said his state had the country's largest deposits of gold and provided a major portion of India's coffee and silk output.
Karnataka was likely to become the centre for private investment in steel and cement by 2000, he said.
"We will be producing more than 18 million tonnes of steel by the year 2000," Deshpande said.
Gujarat's Chief Minister Shanker Sinh Vaghela pointed out that his state was "number one in industrial investment."
He told investors recent political differences had not affected the state's bureaucratic network, which acted swiftly to clear private investment.
